question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
It takes Mary 30 minutes to walk uphill 1 km from her home to school, but it takes her only 10 minutes to walk from school to home along the same route. What is her average speed, in km/hr, for the round trip?
inference:
Walking uphill 1 km takes 30 minutes, therefore, to walk 2 km (the round trip) takes 60 minutes. Walking downhill 1 km takes 10 minutes, therefore, to walk 2 km (the round trip) takes 20 minutes. 

The average speed, in km/hr, is the distance travelled, divided by the time taken. In this case, the distance travelled is 2 km, and the time taken is (60 + 20) / 60 = 13 / 3 hours. Therefore, the average speed is 2 / (13 / 3) = 6 / 13 km/hr.

Final Answer: \boxed{6/13}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: Mary walks a total of 2 km in 40 minutes. Because 40 minutes is 2/3  hr, her average speed, in km/hr, is  $\dfrac{2\text{ km}}{2/3\text{ hr}} = \boxed{3}\text{ km/hr}.$
